p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the 29th report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament.
Chair Mr Ken O'Dowd MP
Deputy Chair Hon Justine Elliot MP
Mrs Bridget Archer MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Ms Gladys Liu MP
Mr Julian Simmonds MP
Mr James Stevens MP
Ms Susan Templeman MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session on 15 July and 11 August 2021
1. The committee resolved to present the following petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 86 petitioners - requesting a ban on the use of certain toxins (EN2801)
From 29 petitioners - requesting dedicated federal quarantine facilities (EN2802)
From 41 petitioners - regarding foreign interference in Australian research institutes and think tanks (EN2804)
From 3412 petitioners - regarding the use of the name 'Persian Gulf' (EN2805)
From 12 petitioners - requesting a clear COVID 19 roadmap to international travel (EN2807)
From 478 petitioners - requesting access to Omnipod insulin pump technology (EN2808)
From 249 petitioners - requesting more regulations for the solar technologyindustry (EN2809)
From 341 petitioners - requesting the Shoalhaven region be designated a distribution priority area for GPs (EN2810)
From 7 petitioners - requesting mandatory organ donation for everyone 18 years of age and over (EN2811)
From 300 petitioners - regarding international travel for vaccinated citizens (EN2812)
From 3408 petitioners - requesting Operation Vest Australia be introduced Australia wide (EN2816)
From 14 petitioners - requesting a stop to mandated English language tests for immigrants (EN2820)
From 6 petitioners - requesting the name of Australia be changed to Royston Vasey (EN2822)
From 14 petitioners - requesting easier terms for fully vaccinated Australians to travel overseas (EN2824)
From 15 petitioners - requesting zero tolerance for violence and gang related fighting (EN2825)
From 7754 petitioners - requesting the cessation of medical coercion (EN2828)
From 33 petitioners - requesting an investigation into epidemiological literature as per the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 (EN2829)
From 37 petitioners - requesting an amendment to the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 (EN2832)
From 5730 petitioners - requesting taxation changes to residency rules (EN2834)
From 33 petitioners - requesting changes to the Veterans' Entitlement Act1986 (EN2835)
From 60 petitioners - requesting the COVID-19 support supplement be reintroduced (EN2837)
From 2082 petitioners - requesting international travel be allowed for vaccinated citizens (EN2839)
From 53 petitioners - requesting the donation of AstraZeneca vaccines to Sri Lanka (EN2841)
From 37 petitioners - requesting a travel exemption for holders of the Prospective Marriage Visa (EN2842)
From 95 petitioners - requesting a ban on genetically modified agricultural crops (EN2846)
From 25 petitioners - regarding the cost of education (EN2847)
From 4847 petitioners - requesting that vaccines not be made mandatory (EN2849)
From 31 petitioners - requesting further action to protect children from COVID-19 (EN2850)
From 54 petitioners - requesting for off-grid, modular, foundationless homes to be legal on all urban lots (EN2854)
From 96616 petitioners - requesting alternate treatment options for COVID-19 (EN2855)
From 8240 petitioners - requesting that the reuniting of families be prioritised in any international travel roadmap (EN2856)
From 156 petitioners - requesting equality for approvals of international travel exemptions (EN2857)
From 3559 petitioners - requesting a stop to COVID-19 vaccines without informed consent (EN2858)
From 242 petitioners - requesting free emergency and compassionate travel for Australians fully vaccinated against COVID-19 (EN2859)
From 2288 petitioners - requesting official recognition of national missing persons week (EN2862)
From 53 petitioners - requesting that bus drivers be included as frontline workers and prioritised for COVID-19 vaccines (EN2863)
From 24 petitioners - requesting the Australian Dollar be renamed to 'dollarbucks' (EN2864)
From 150 petitioners - requesting a withdrawal of the COVID Safe app (EN2865)
From 4712 petitioners - regarding passenger caps on international travel (EN2867)
From 7048 petitioners - requesting that the AstraZeneca vaccine be donated to Bangladesh on humanitarian grounds (EN2869)
From 35 petitioners - requesting the Census not be compulsory (EN2870)
From 398 petitioners - regarding international travel (EN2875)
From 32 petitioners - requesting the Pfizer vaccine be made free and available to people over 60 years (EN2876)
From 10 petitioners - requesting a ban on all wood and open fireplaces (EN2878)
From 26 petitioners - requesting updates to the petitions system web pages (EN2881)
From 243 petitioners - requesting that the AstraZeneca vaccine not be made available for anyone (EN2882)
From 302 petitioners - requesting that international borders be open (EN2883)
From 2132 petitioners - requesting that COVID-19 vaccines not be made mandatory for aged care workers (EN2886)
From 69 petitioners - requesting that people vaccinated against COVID-19 be excluded from any COVID-19 related restrictions (EN2887)
From 69 petitioners - requesting meat resellers be mandated to declare added water content in products (EN2888)
From 858 petitioners - requesting for the prayers at the commencement of each sitting of the House be replaced with a more inclusive option (EN2895)
From 5903 petitioners - requesting that COVID-19 vaccines not be made mandatory for aged care workers (EN2901)
From 48 petitioners - requesting that all social media accounts be made verifiable (EN2904)
From 19297 petitioners - requesting that coercion towards medical intervention, procedure, or treatment be criminalised (EN2912)
From 2280 petitioners - requesting subsidies for the FreeStyle Libre Flash Glucose Monitoring System for Australians living with diabetes (EN2914)

span.span: The following ministerial responses to petitions were received:
Received by the Committee on 11 August 2021

p.span: From the Assistant Treasurer - to a petition concerning the acquisition of Bellamy's Australia Ltd by China Mengniu Dairy Company Limited (EN1182)
From the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet - to a petition requesting the House call for a no-confidence motion against the Prime Minister (EN1246)
From the Assistant Treasurer - to a petition requesting that any assets owned in full or partly by the Chinese Communist Party be seized (EN1520)
From the Assistant Treasurer - to a petition concerning JobKeeper and JobSeeker payment entitlement differences (EN1727)
From the Attorney-General - to a petition requesting a referendum for the removal of state governments (EN1890)
From the Assistant Treasurer - to a petition requesting an extension of the JobKeeper support payment to the aviation sector, or an aviation industry wage subsidy and rescue package (EN2404)

From the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts - to a petition requesting to expedite works to improve mobile coverage in the Clyde and Clyde North areas of Victoria (EN2412)

From the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts - to a petition requesting to deny health experts access to the 'live list' of online misinformation due to the concern of infringing people's freedom of speech (EN2421)
From the Assistant Treasurer - to a petition concerning Medicare Levy payments (EN2497)
From the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts - to a petition concerning unsolicited emails from charities (EN2506)
From the Attorney-General - to a petition concerning a motion presented by Senator Malcom Roberts opposing the use of gender-neutral language (EN2533)
From the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts - to a petition requesting to make the National Relay Service registration optional for its users (EN2604)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs - to a petition concerning events in Tigray, Ethiopia (EN2613)
From the Minister for Home Affairs - to a petition concerning the inclusion of parents as immediate family members as an automatic exemption from Australia's travel restrictions (EN2630)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care - to a petition concerning freedom of choice for Australians regarding COVID-19 vaccinations (EN2633)
From the Minister for Home Affairs - to a petition concerning Australians travelling to India to support sick family members (EN2641)
PETITIONS
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, I present the following 55 petitions:
Feral Animals

Sodium fluoroacetate, commonly called 1080, is a poison used extensively to kill "pest" species, but also affects all living species, including plants, insects, birds, and humans. It causes birth defects and damage to the reproductive system, brain, heart, and other organs. There are reports that the Nazis considered using the poison on Jewish prisoners in concentration camps, but decided not to because of the danger to the guards. In addition, poisoned animals may contaminate nearby waterways. Faecal contamination of waterways by species killed by 1080 has been raised as an issue in parliamentary enquiries. Highly soluble, it spreads very quickly through water and up food chains. Its presence is difficult to detect, making it a plausible weapon in bioterrorism. 1080 causes a great suffering, but doesn't provide a real solution to environmental damage from introduced or "pest" species. The so-called "culling" of animals is neither a suitable nor an effective method of limiting populations. In fact, it can often lead to an increase in the number of animals present in a given area, as it creates a more suitable habitat for increased reproduction. 1080 is still used in Australia and New Zealand. It is banned in most countries, the US, outlawed it in the early 1970s because of civilian deaths.

We therefore ask the House to introduce federal legislation banning the use of toxins that indiscriminately harm the land we live off, our native and domestic animals and provide no real change in population of feral animals including 1080.
from 86 citizens (Petition No. EN2801)
COVID-19: International Travel
The Federal Government's current strategy for attempting to prevent/eradicate COVID-19 within Australia is crippling our people, businesses, industries and our future.

This justification for preventing Australians (citizens, residents and businesses) from moving freely (both inter-state and internationally) is extremely detrimental to our individual wellbeing and future as a country. Australians have now become prisoners in their own country.

Australia's past success as a nation has been in its ability to connect with and welcome travellers and opportunities from all over the world. We do not have the population to maintain a healthy and thriving economy on our own.
Australia cannot survive in isolation from the rest of the world.

Secondly, by setting up dedicated quarantine facilities, not only will this ease the burden of hotel quarantine, it will also mitigate the risk of hotel quarantine breaches and community outbreaks, and also allow for a greater capacity to manage incoming travellers and returning Australians.

We therefore ask the House to set up multiple dedicated federal quarantine facilities to manage incoming travellers. This will ensure that Australia is not only prepared for COVID-19, but also for future pandemics.
And we ask for our international borders to be reopened and for all Australian citizens and residents to be able to move freely internationally.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN2802)
International Relations

There are research institutes in Australia that claim to be geopolitics, policy, defence, cybersecurity, and intelligence think tanks. One of these in particular is funded significantly by foreign arms and military technology manufacturers.

The think tank in question not only produces an enormous amount of output that is clearly marketing (including viral, nudge, and indirect marketing) for foreign military and armaments businesses, but is significantly funded by Australia's taxpayers through defence budgets.

That think tank or research/policy institute has close financial and business ties with foreign manufacturers of military technology that are almost certainly necessarily affiliated with various Western, foreign security and intelligence agencies in the US, UK, France, and other parts of Europe.
Australian taxpayers should not be financing the marketing of foreign weapons and weapons technology to Australia.
Australian think tanks and policy shops should not be engaged in marketing and political activism that is influenced by foreign intelligence agenices connected with foreign military tech makers.

We therefore ask the House to conduct reviews into the actions and funding of Australian policy think tanks that use taxpayer funds to market foreign military technology in, and to, Australia, and have strong ties to US and European arms manufacturers. Furthermore, that such policy and research shops and research institutes that have these financial and business relationships should be investigated to ensure that foreign interference and influence laws are not being violated - particularly with respect to the influence of foreign intelligence agencies based in the UK and USA (CC 92.7-9).
from 41 citizens (Petition No. EN2804)
Middle East

Australia is land of migrants. Like trees, human being have their roots spread in their values and traditions. After migration, still part of that root stays in the origin although this tree starts to spread roots in the new motherland and begin to flourish new roots and branches. Countries in the world experience ups and downs but in the end nations have proven to rise from their ashes. Iran (Persia) is a country that has experienced significant falls and rises in the past 3000 years. Right or wrong, whether by nation's choice or by the world's influence, in 1979 Iranian's regime changed. Persian culture promotes respect and tolerance. As Persians Australians, we expect Australian Government also to respect Iran's great contribution to the world's heritage regardless of the current challenges. It is heartbreaking to witness that Australian Government, Media and Education System have been aiding to distort Persian heritage. For thousands of years, Persian Gulf has been known as Persian Gulf. According to the world map published by the United Nations "Map No.4102 Rev.5, Nov 2011" the gulf that is located in the south of Iran is officially called and known as Persian Gulf. There is no Arabian Gulf or Gulf.

We therefore ask the House to mandate using the right and true name for the Persian Gulf across Australian government, Media and Education System. It is absolutely devastating to see some books at schools promoting incorrect names such as Gulf or Arabian Gulf.
from 3,412 citizens (Petition No. EN2805)
COVID-19: International Travel

Currently around 7.5 million Australians born overseas are unable to see family members and with no end in sight or plan this is impacting mental health and even causing them to leave what was considered their home.
We are asking the Federal Government to outline a clear roadmap with dates and meaningful targets to be able to stop Lockdowns and work towards International travel. This should include:
1) Onshore manufacturing investment, scale dates and vaccination production targets.
2) Clear target dates for vaccine accessibility for all age groups.
3) Phase out dates of Hotel Quarantine, based on vaccine coverage % and vaccination status.
4) Open dates for International borders, based on vaccine coverage % and vaccination status.
We therefore ask the House to outline a clear COVID Roadmap towards 0 Lockdowns and International travel with dates and targets that they are accountable for.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN2807)
Diabetes

The Omnipod Insulin Pump received TGA approval in 2010 for use in Australia. The parent company lodged an application with the Prosthesis Listing Advisory Committee in August 2020 for the February 2021 meeting. The application was delayed by PLAC requesting more information. The next meeting was held in May 2021 and to date, no official response has been received by Omnipod. The mechanism for assessing novel technology and subsequent reimbursement on NDSS is slow and outdated which removes a persons access and choice to diabetes technology.

We therefore ask the House to review the specific methods of how PLAC and NDSS are approaching this application to ensure that those living with diabetes have responsive and affordable access to diabetes insulin pump technology.
from 478 citizens (Petition No. EN2808)
Renewable Energy

In Australia some businesses sell solar without any training, licencing or insurance. They offer very low cost solar but typically the products used and installation quality is of a low standard. Once these businesses are unable to pay their staff, contractors and/or the ATO OR have too many after sales installation and warranty issues they typically end up filing for bankruptcy. This leaves alot of Australian residents without any product / workmanship warranty or after sales support on their solar systems.
This also leads to alot of landfill issues and is not achieving the desired outcomes for the environment and action on climate change.
Almost 1/3 of all solar system owners can now be described as solar orphans.
We therefore ask the House to

change the federal laws so that any business selling solar power systems should either hold an Electrical Contractors Licence and/or Builders Licence in the State/s that they operate. Any business that is currently unlicensed should be given 90 days to obtain licencing or cease trading.
Any individual who sells a solar system in Australia should be trained as a CEC accredited designer.
We also ask the House to Initiate a publicly available national register of solar businesses.
This publicly available register should show all major defects and complaints made against all Solar Businesses.
Any solar business that is declared insolvent should be shut down and the information displayed on the register.
Solar businesses that receive excessive complaints should have their ability to trade suspended until sufficient resolutions are met.
from 249 citizens (Petition No. EN2809)
Shoalhaven: Health Care

The Department of Health thinks that much of the Shoalhaven has enough GPs, so are not Distribution Priority Areas (DPA). Therefore, most International and some Australian Medical Graduates can't work here. With less than 4% of all Australian Medical Graduates choosing to be rural GPs, Shoalhaven practices can't replace their retiring GPs or plan for community growth.

The Department counts Medicare items to decide DPA. They don't consider poor public transport, overcrowded emergency departments, ambulance ramping, or some of the State's worst hospital waiting lists. The demand forces GPs to see lots of patients quickly, so Medicare "looks" like there are plenty of appointments. In reality, patients get little time with their doctor, doctors get over-worked and burned out, and everyone suffers.

It also doesn't consider what doctors do. GPs who supervise trainees, do home and aged care visits, take calls overnight, provide specialised care - like mental health or women's health - won't show up with Medicare as much as doctors seeing 6 patients per hour in their office. So the loss of some GPs will barely show up on the DPA radar, even though it leaves a major hole in the community.
DPA restrictions for GPs are not the only problem, but they are a big part of it, and it's damaging the health of the Shoalhaven. The Department has the power to fix it.
We therefore ask the House to permanently reverse the non-DPA status of the whole Shoalhaven region.
from 341 citizens (Petition No. EN2810)
Organ and Tissue Donation
Most people don't take the time to register for organ donation but would be happy to be organ donors.
As a result we should make all citizens over the age of 18 automatic organ donors provided they don't have any health condition to stop them from doing so.

People would of course have the option to take them selves off the organ donor list at any point in time, however, if they choose to do so, a person on the organ donor list would be prioritised over a person who removed themselves off the organ donor list. Any person who cannot be on the organ donor list for medical reasons is exempt from the prioritising rule.

An organ donor register already exists, with minor changes all citizens can be added to the register and we would have the chance to save so many more of our community members and minimise medical resources and wait times.
It makes no sense to have perfectly healthy organs not being used simply because most people don't take 5min out of their day to register.
We therefore ask the House to consider the above proposal and implement a system which gives our community and medical system the best opportunity for success.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN2811)
COVID-19: International Travel
Why can't the Federal Government publish a road map (with timeframes and criteria) for reopening international boarders?
Given millions of Australians have family overseas, why can't the Federal Government allow vaccinated Australians to travel overseas (at their own risk) and allow home quarantining upon their return?

For some Australians it's been years since they have seen their family, it's inhumane to shut the boarders long term and with no plan for reopening its especially hard on people's mental health. I understand why the international boarders were shut at the start of the pandemic, but given the vaccine rollout is progressing, vaccinated travellers should be allowed to travel freely and without draconian exemption requests.
What is the policy here? Shutting boarders for the next 2-3 years to maintain COVID zero? That's neither sustainable nor realistic in the long term.
If you allow vaccinated Australians to travel, this will also help the thousands of Australians still stuck overseas to get back home.

Both public and businesses need a commitment from the Federal Government when international boarders will reopen. We need more than simply 'when the health advice says it's safe to reopen'. The Federal Government has had months to devise a detailed plan for reopening, therefore it's time to share this and allow Australians to travel again.

We therefore ask the House to ask the Federal Government to allow vaccinated Australians to travel overseas and allow them to quarantine at home upon their return. Finally publish a road map for reopening international boarders.
from 300 citizens (Petition No. EN2812)
Domestic, Family and Sexual Violence

Operation Vest which was introduced into NSW has made it easier & less invasive for survivors to report crimes of sexual assault. The digital form SARO gives victims options to report a crime committed against them, outside the court proceedings. This will lessen the re-traumatisation amongst victims alongside raise the amount of known reports about sexual assault australia-wide. This database is important to keep track of repeat offenders alongside normalising the reporting of sexual assault & rape & empowering victims to feel heard.
We therefore ask the House to apply Operation Vest Australia-wide alongside the database SARO for sexual assault survivors country-wide.
from 3,408 citizens (Petition No. EN2816)
Skilled Migration Program

Some skilled immigrants who have had thier basic, secondary and tertiary education in English language have been subjected to the gruesome, money gulping inefficient scheme of assessment called PTE (PEARSON TEST) or IELTS (INTERNATIONAL ENGLISH LANGUAGE TESTING SYSTEM). You will find that countries in need to skilled workers are using these exams to milk thier immigrants of the funds they barely have.

The sad part is that these exams are even too complex for a native English speaker to pass, some test takers have questioned thier intellectual capabilities because of a language test, and ultimately after severely passing the exam, it expires after 3years if you don't use it for the immigration purpose; back to the rat race!

Ps: what is the ethics or justification for making a permanent resident go through the same English test if the person passed the citizen test that was conducted in "ENGLISH". Is the aim to ensure all your citizens that didn't buy their citizenship or colonise someone for it know how to use thier tenses perfectly to be a barrister, fruit picker, cleaner or caregiver???
We therefore ask the House to
convince the department of home affairs and immigration service to ease off on these exams, channel it to where and who necessary and let ONE SUCESS BE ENOUGH!
HELP US SIGN AND SHARE TILL IT REACHES WHO NEEDS TO DO THIS TO SLEEP BETTER AT NIGHT.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN2820)
Australian Society
New name would be more accurately describe the nation today.
We therefore ask the House to change te name of Australia to Royston Vasey.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN2822)
COVID-19: International Travel

Australia is currently closed to the outside world. People can't travel and for good reason - the health of Australians should be top priority! However, the economic and mental health cost for most Australians cannot be ignored anymore. More than 30% Australians (not including countless other permanent residents) have family overseas and to not see them for over a year and a half (and counting) has taken a bad toll on their mental health. On the country wide scale, the Australian economy has taken a great hit too. Therefore we request that as the vaccine is rolled out we should have relaxed restrictions for Australian citizens and residents for international travel. Most other countries like the US and UK have already relaxed restrictions for their vaccinated citizens. Therefore, Australia should follow suit and finally put an end to what has been unprecedented two years.

We therefore ask the House to mandate easier terms for fully vaccinated Australians returning from overseas. Perhaps, a fews days hotel quarantine and if you test negative then released to home quarantine with some follow-up Covid tests? A negative test prior to travel and a second test in hotel quarantine covers the incubation period, add that to the fact you're fully vaccinated and you present no more threat to the community than people already in Australia. This will free up places in hotel quarantine for other travellers too and reduce the exposure of people catching Covid.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN2824)
Law Enforcement

Nationally the gang related fights & random acts of violence have been on the rise. They are not being managed accordingly. Recently a 15year old boy was left fighting for his life after a group of 50+ teens were involved in a fight in Mc Donalds at Tea Tree Plaza shopping centre. We have a right to be safe & not be exposed to such violence. Many incidents of this kind & gang culture involve people whom originate from overseas. We must ACT NOW to ensure harsher penalties & ensure we demonstrate ZERO tolerance of this behaviour regardless of your origin. There is no excuse for violence, especially those trying to create a gang culture it is not what we stand for in Australia. Many people would love the opportunity to live here, we should not allow any persons whom commits such crime to have the privilege of living in Australia. Deport those who are not abiding by the law & leave room for those who will be contributing members of society to migrate here. This is NOT about race, it's about setting a standard of acceptable behaviour in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to review the current management of these incidents and adjust the laws to be stricter on gang violence / random acts of violence in society. Review the laws of those whom are not citizens to be deported if they are caught participating in any gang related violence / crime.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN2825)
COVID-19: Vaccination

It's not only harming the current vaccine roll-out and people's confidence in the vaccines, but also confidence in the authorities and their messaging. Coercion in the form of limiting freedoms of movement (or even suggesting such limitations) limiting access to services or restricting employment is not a scientifically proven way of increasing vaccine uptake and in all likelihood is highly damaging for this purpose. It is also a direct violation of human rights.

It is harmful, discriminatory and dangerous at a time when Australia needs to have trust in the authorities and be unified in the face of our current social challenges. It could be argued that medical coercion is counterproductive for public health outcomes.

We therefore ask the House to outlaw all forms of medical coercion in Australia immediately. This includes coercion through limiting freedoms of movement (as recently suggested by the AMA and some Government MPs) for those who are not vaccinated, suggesting limitations to such movement, limiting access to services or restrictions on employment. Coercive measures are in direct contravention to the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki for medical ethics (which superseded the Nuremberg Code).
from 7,754 citizens (Petition No. EN2828)
Veterans

In 1994 Parliament made such amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, that allowed for the creation of the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA), and for the RMA to have such powers to decide on Statement of Principles (SoP).
SoPs legislate the factors, one of which must exist before it can be said that, death, injury or disease is connected with the circumstances of a person's relevant service.

In 1996 the then Government honored an election pledge to undertake a review into the RMA and the Specialist Medical Review Council, the review entity. In 1997 Professor Dennis Pearce completed this review.

In November 1998 the RMA and DVA hosted a forum in response to the recommendations of Professor Pearce. At that forum Professor Ken Donald Chairman RMA stated, "This is where we have enormous trouble because most of the epidemiological literature was never assembled and written for the purpose that we are now using it. It was written for all sorts of purposes: public health, advancement of people's careers; all sorts of reasons. But it was not written specifically to be used for this sort of social purpose".
Professor Donald's comment raises a question as to whether the literature he is referring to is lawfully relevant, and fit for purpose.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes, as to cause a contemporary investigation into the RMA be undertaken, with at least one of the terms of reference questioning the relevance and veracity of said epidemiological literature.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN2829)
Veterans

Under the Repatriation Act 1920(RA), provisions were made for a Veteran Applicant to appeal a matter relating to question of law to the Federal Court, s107VZZH, s107VZZJ, s107VZZK and s107VZZL. Included in these provision were allowances that costs be borne by the Commonwealth, and in some instances the Attorney General could approve legal/financial assistance.

A reasonable person would conclude this provision was designed to balance out the fact that under EAs107VU Parliament had decided to deprive an applicant from representation by a legal practitioner at the review proceedings. Ordinarily it would be this legal practitioner that would safeguard the Applicants natural justice entitlements.

These sections of the RA did not migrate the Veterans Entitlement Act 1986(VEA) in the same manner as advice relating to appealing a matter to the AAT, or the continuance of the prohibition on legal representation.

In response to Parliamentary Petition EN1172 the then Minister Chester stated, "it is widely acknowledged the VEA is unnecessarily complex", the Minister also alludes to the value of "judicial guidance".
Despite being, "unnecessarily complex", very few Veteran matters are appealed to Federal Court, perhaps because of ignorance, and for others, there is the issue of costs.
Amending the VEA and MRCA to mirror the RA will encourage appeals to Federal Court, with any "judicial guidance" providing clarity, on this "unnecessarily complex", legislation to the benefit to all.
We therefore ask the House to cause an amendment to the VEA and MRCA to that which mirrors these sections of the Repatriation Act 1920.
from 37 citizens (Petition No. EN2832)
COVID-19: Taxation
The March 2019 Board of Taxation Residency Report proposed Factor Test does not achieve the goals of appropriate, fair or simple and is not an effective method in dealing with residency because:
1. The 45 day period is too short:
a. It does not account for 14 day Quarantine requirements,
b. School holidays are over 10 weeks, so any genuine non resident seeking to bring his family for extended vacation would be captured,
c. Vacation travel is likely to be longer in a post covid19 world due to travel costs, uncertainty, and quarantining requirements,
d. The short period may be detrimental to international businesses willingness to travel and engage with Australia.
2. The suggested 4 questions of the Factor Test are too simple and likely to adversely impact anyone that is innocently visiting, investing or interacting with Australia economically.
3. Against the intent of this change it is likely that any genuine Australian citizen non resident, would have 2 of the test questions
We therefore ask the House to prior to the final drafting and presentation of law on this matter, the Parliament consider and implement that:
1. The 45 day test be extended to 90 days and that;
a. Any period of forced Quarantine not be included in the day count, and
b. Any period of genuine required work/business not be included in the day count to continue to encourage ongoing economic activity and international trade.

2. The 4 point test be expanded to allow more appropriate assessment and consider using a weighted average point score based on responses to provide a more fair, relevant and understandable method of assessment.
from 5,730 citizens (Petition No. EN2834)
Veterans

Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) s196B details the Functions of Repatriation Medial Authority (RMA), the main function of which is to determine Statements of Principles for the purposes of the VEA and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act.

In creating this section of the Act, Parliament has unfairly weighted the determination process against those with entitlements under the "beneficial" Veterans Acts, by not requiring the RMA to issue a written "reason for decision".

Requiring the RMA to give a written reason for decision would engage the Acts Interpretation Act 1901s25D, and result in the RMA having to, "set out the findings on material questions of fact and refer to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based".

This would provide significant clarity on how the RMA arrives at its determinations to the largely medically unqualified Veteran Community and Advocates, treating Doctors and Specialists, Legal Representatives, as well as the appropriate professional medical associations and bodies, and other interested persons.

Further, where appropriate this would expose the administrative/medical determination of the RMA to the wisdom and interpretation of the Federal Court, and in doing so restore balance and natural justice to what the undersigned believe to be an unfairly weighted RMA determination process.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such amendments to the VEA that results in the RMA having to give a written reason for decision when it makes a determination, and thus restore balance and natural justice to the arguably unfairly weighted RMA determination process.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN2835)
COVID-19: Income Support Payments

Covid is still around and people are still financially struggling due to businesses needing to close or not being able to pay that many people or have that many people employed in the one space. With not being to afford rent, bills or food. Covid is obviously not gonna and matters need to happen to help Australians cope
We therefore ask the House to think about bringing back the fortnightly or weekly Covid payment. Whether it's only $250 or the full $550 we started with. Something to help the economy to survive
from 60 citizens (Petition No. EN2837)
COVID-19: International Travel

Whilst Australia keeps shutting down interstate borders and imposing restrictions on businesses for a minute number of Covid cases, Europe is opening its borders without quarantine to fully vaccinated travellers.
How much longer are we going to be the isolated village of the world?
I say open all vaccines now, to everybody, any age, any vaccine. If you want it you can have it.
And give a date. For example say, from 1 January 2022, anyone can travel in or out of Australia if they are fully vaccinated (2 jabs).
This international lockdown cannot continue. We are hurting friends, family, students and skilled workers. It is making us the pariah of the world.
We therefore ask the House to
Open the borders outbound to fully vaccinated Australian Citizens and Permanent Residents and open the borders inbound for foreigners on any type of visa.

from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN2850)
Housing Affordability

Due to the real estate industry and rising housing prices, owning a home has become prohibitively expensive for many Australians. Many Australians are in the very real and difficult position of never being able to afford their own home.

However, solutions to the housing crisis exist in the form of various kinds of new technologies for creating modular homes at low cost, and for powering those homes off-grid using alternative power sources. Some of these modular, engineered types of homes do not even require foundations.

Modular homes, tiny houses, and shipping-crate based homes offer enormous financial relief and provide a way for many who would otherwise not be able to afford to live independently in their own home to do so.
Such homes also allow the homeowner to gradually develop their premises whilst living in it, by adding modules.

Excluding builders and building approval procedures and rules, eliminating stamp duties and taxes for modular homes, and making off-grid modular homes legal on all urban lots and blocks, are measures that are now a social necessity.
A corresponding significant reduction in, or even elimination, of council rates pertaining to self sustaining utilities is also necessary.

We therefore ask the House to pass legislation enabling piece-wise establishment of modular, prefabricated, fold-out, and engineered homes to be established legally on any urban block or lot in Australia without any licensed builder involvement, to make legal the use of off grid alternative power solutions for such premises, and to eliminate all taxes and stamp duties for such premises.

from 242 citizens (Petition No. EN2859)
National Missing Persons Week
Over 40,000 people are reported missing in Australia each year. While most are found within a week, around 800 become long term missing persons.

For every person that goes missing, research has shown that at least 12 people are directly affected; financially, emotionally and psychologically. The families and friends of missing persons are confronted with profound and complex challenges they never imagined they'd have to face, and they must navigate this alone.

We - Missing Persons Advocacy Network (MPAN) - are the only organisation in Australia committed to humanising missing persons, creating awareness for the associated issues, and providing critical support to those left behind.

Established by the family of missing WA man Tony Jones in 1988, National Missing Persons Week (1-8 August 2021) is a platform for raising much needed awareness of missing persons in Australia. For MPAN, the week is our biggest opportunity to tell the stories of the loved ones we work with, give Australians an insight into the impacts of ambiguous loss, and generate widespread community support.
Unfortunately, there is currently no official recognition of National Missing Persons Week in place by the Australian Government.

Officially recognising National Missing Persons Week in Australia goes beyond the week's recognition. It is also a clear demonstration that the Australian Government acknowledges and stands with the thousands of Australians plagued by missingness every day.
We therefore ask the House to encourage the Australian Government to officially recognise National Missing Persons Week (commencing the first Sunday of August, annually).

Parliament
Each sitting day, the Speaker begins proceedings by reciting this prayer:

"Almighty God, we humbly beseech Thee to vouch safe Thy blessing upon this Parliament. Direct and prosper our deliberations to the advancement of Thy glory, and the true welfare of the people of Australia. Our Father, which art in Heaven: Hallowed be Thy Name. Thy Kingdom come. Thy will be done in earth, as it is in Heaven. Give us this day our daily bread. And forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive them that trespass against us. And lead us not into temptation; but deliver us from evil: For Thine is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory, forever and ever. Amen."
This practice of reciting an exclusively Christian prayer discriminates against non-Christians. It sends a message that non-Christians are not welcome and not equal.

Supporters of the prayer claim it's part of a tradition from 1901 which must be maintained. But Australia has changed, and so should this practice. In the 1901 Census, 96% of Australians identified as Christian. In the 2016 Census, only 52% did.
This House will soon consider a Religious Discrimination Bill. It would be hypocritical to consider that legislation while subjecting non-Christians to such a discriminatory practice.

We therefore ask the House to show its respect for the diversity of Australians and its commitment to the principles of freedom of religion and freedom from religion by replacing the public prayer with a moment of silence for reflection or silent private prayer.

from 2,280 citizens (Petition No. EN2914)
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the following 16 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Foreign Investment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for the Standing Committee on Petitions' correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1182 - the acquisition of Bellamy's Australia Ltd (Bellamy's) by China Mengniu Dairy Company Limited (China Mengniu).

Consistent with the unanimous recommendation of the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB), in November 2019 the Treasurer concluded the acquisition of Bellamy's by China Mengniu is not contrary to the national interest, subject to the imposition of enforceable conditions. FIRB made its recommendation after undertaking an extensive period of consultation that considered a wide range of issues.

The conditions imposed on China Mengniu include that: a majority of the Bellamy's Board of Directors must be Australian resident citizens; Bellamy's must keep its headquarters in Australia for at least 10 years; and Bellamy's must invest at least $12 million to establish or improve infant milk formula processing facilities in Victoria. These conditions will ensure Bellamy's maintains its presence in Australia, and that it proceeds with a previously announced investment in infant milk formula processing facilities. The conditions are enforceable. Penalties apply for non-compliance.

This approval ensures Bellamy's can continue to support jobs in Australia and strengthen its ability to expand its domestic market as well as its export opportunities, particularly into the growing Asian market. The decision also provide opportunities for the suppliers that contribute to Bellamy's products, including Australian dairy farmers.
The parties announced this sale agreement on 25 November 2019, ten days after Mengniu was granted conditional approval to acquire Bellamy's.

You may be aware that following its acquisition of Bellamy's, China Mengniu sought to acquire Lion Dairy and Drinks from Japanese company Kirin for $600 million. On 24 August 2020, the parties announced they would not be proceeding with the sale after the Treasurer indicated to the applicant that approval would not be forthcoming. In a statement to the media, the Treasurer said the parties' announcement followed "the communication of my preliminary view to Mengniu Dairy that the proposed acquisition would be contrary to the national interest."
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Prime Minister
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 3 June 2021 referring petition EN1246 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf. I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding.
Australia is taking strong climate action as part of a coordinated global effort. We have a strong track record of achieving and exceeding our commitments - and it is clear our policies are working.

We have met and exceeded our Kyoto commitments by 459 million tonnes, and our emissions are down 20 per cent from 2005 levels. We are well on the way to meet and beat our Paris commitment - reducing emissions by 26 to 28 per cent on 2005 levels by 2030. Achieving our 2030 target will see our emissions per capita fall by almost half, and by 70 per cent per unit of GDP.

We are on the pathway to net zero. Our goal is to get there as soon as we possibly can by investing in technology that enables and transforms our industries - and not through taxes that eliminates them, and the jobs and livelihoods they support and create.

For Australia, it is not a question of if or when we will reach net zero, but importantly how. That is why we are investing in priority new technology solutions, through our Technology Investment Roadmap initiative. We are investing around $20 billion to achieve ambitious goals that will bring the cost of clean hydrogen, green steel, energy storage and carbon capture to commercial parity. We expect this to secure more than $80 billion in total investment in the decade ahead.

Annual Low Emissions Technology Statements are key milestones of the Roadmap process, and will detail the impact of our investments and our progress towards clearly defined priority technology stretch goals, informed by advice from the Technology Investment Advisory Council chaired by Dr Alan Finkel. Technology neutrality is fundamental to this approach, meaning all available technologies need to be on the table for Australia to achieve global climate goals.

Through our $1.6 billion emission reduction package announced in the 2021-22 Budget, the Government is investing $275.5 million to accelerate the development of clean hydrogen hubs in regional Australia. These will transform Australia's transport industries, mining and resource sectors, manufacturing, and fuel and energy production.

This package will also foster international collaboration to achieve technology breakthroughs, lower energy costs and create more than 6,000 jobs, especially in our regions. Our approach is working: we've already announced international partnerships with Germany, Japan and Singapore to accelerate the development of industries like hydrogen and create new jobs, and we look forward to finalising a partnership with the United Kingdom.
In the 2021-22 Budget, the Government also committed $30.6 million to restore and account for blue carbon ecosystems, which play a key role in drawing carbon out of the atmosphere.

These investments complement existing policies, including the $1.9 billion investment in low emissions technologies announced in the 2020-21 Budget, which included $1.62 billion for the Australian Renewable Energy Agency, as well as our Climate Solutions Package and the Emissions Reduction Fund.

So far under the Emissions Reduction Fund we have secured over 200 million tonnes of emissions reductions, and new methods continue to be developed. In June 2021, the Government released a draft carbon capture and storage method for consultation. Dr Fatih Birol, Executive Director of the International Energy Agency, has said carbon capture and storage will be critical to meeting global climate goals.
Australia is making a strong contribution to the global effort of tackling climate change while ensuring we continue to build a strong job creating economy.
Thank you for taking the time to raise this important issue.
Yours sincerely,
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Foreign Investment
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1520 - Chinese investment in Australia. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Foreign investment provides significant benefits to Australia. It is important for economic growth and job creation, and it contributes to the prosperity of businesses, communities, and the overall economy. Without foreign investment, Australia's production, employment, and income would all be lower. At the same time, the Government recognises that foreign investments must be in the national interest.

Foreign investment from China, as from other countries, is managed through Australia's foreign investment review framework. This framework strikes a balance between ensuring we remain an attractive investment destination and upholding the national interest so that Australians can be confident in the benefits of foreign investment. If it is determined that a proposed investment is contrary to Australia's national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

The countries with the largest stock of foreign direct investment in Australia are our traditional trading partners in the United States (19.1 per cent of the total stock of foreign direct investment as at 31 December 2020), Japan (12.8 per cent) and the United Kingdom (12.0 per cent). China's share is comparatively small, at 4.3 per cent of Australia's total foreign direct investment stock.

Comprehensive reforms to the foreign investment review framework came into effect from 1 January 2021. These reforms update the framework in three broad ways: they address national security risks; strengthen the existing system, particularly as it relates to compliance by foreign investors; and streamline investment in non-sensitive businesses.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
JobSeeker Payment
JobKeeper Payment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1727 - JobSeeker and JobKeeper entitlement differences. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The JobKeeper Payment was always intended to be a temporary program designed to support confidence and get businesses back up and running as soon as possible. It was designed to deliver support quickly and at scale and it has played a crucial role in supporting and driving the economy, keeping businesses in business and individuals connected to their employer. JobKeeper supported nearly half of Australian businesses and one-third of all workers.

From 1 April 2021, the Government permanently increased the base rate of working age income support payments by $50 per fortnight, and permanently increased the income free area for JobSeeker Payment, Youth Allowance (other), and Parenting Payment Partnered to $150 per fortnight, allowing recipients to earn more each fortnight before their payment reduces. These changes aim to get the balance right between providing support for people and incentives to work, as the nation moves away from relying on the emergency supports in place over the past year.

Australia's income support system is part of a wide-ranging welfare system that assists people through provision of a range of cash payments, services and support programs. The Government has been committed to temporary, targeted and scalable support during the pandemic. The Government will continue to make sure that our welfare system is targeted and comprehensive, with a range of supports that recognise the individual needs of Australians who need support.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Australian Constitution
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 7 July 2021 regarding the House of Representatives' Petition EN1890 requesting a referendum for removal of state governments. The petition requests a referendum to remove state governments on the basis that state governments have put in place unrealistic COVID-19 border restrictions.

Enclosed in your email was a letter dated 9 November 2020 to the former Attorney-General, the Hon Christian Porter MP, in which you referred the petition to the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General's Department apologises for the failure to respond to your previous letter. The Department has been unable to confirm receipt of the previous letter.

A number of states and territories have taken measures under their own laws, including public health and emergency management legislation, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Throughout the pandemic, the Australian Government has worked cooperatively with states and territories, and will continue to do so.

Section 128 of the Constitution requires that a referendum be held to make any alteration to the Constitution. In order to be effective, a proposed amendment of the Constitution must be approved at a national referendum by a majority of voters overall and by majorities in a majority of states (that is, in four of the six states). The Government does not propose to seek to change the Constitution to remove state governments.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Aviation Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2404 - Extending JobKeeper to the Aviation Sector or by offering a specific Aviation Industry wage subsidy and rescue package. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

While the path to recovery is well underway, the Australian Government appreciates public health measures, international passenger caps and quarantine arrangements continue to affect Australia's aviation sector. In recognition of this and the importance of the aviation sector to the economy and Australia more broadly, the Government is providing $1.8 billion in targeted support to the aviation and tourism sectors in 2021-22 Budget. This brings total targeted support to the aviation sector to $4.5 billion since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The targeted support package is part of the next phase of the Government's National Economic Recovery Plan with support helping to maintain essential air services, boost domestic tourism in our regions and protect aviation jobs. Consistent with the principles that have guided the Government's response to the pandemic, economic support in the post JobKeeper period will be temporary, targeted, proportionate and have a clear exit strategy.

Government support includes support for both domestic and international aviation recognising the two subsectors have different barriers to recovery in the short term. On the international side the Government is providing up to $200 million for the International Aviation Support measure, which will maintain a core Australian international aviation workforce of up to 8000 workers until October 2021. This funding will help preserve international aviation jobs, aviation skills and facilitate a quick resumption of international travel when restrictions are eased.

Simultaneously, the Government is also ensuring businesses in regional Australia remain connected to key international markets by extending the International Freight Assistance Mechanism. In addition to these measures, the Government is negotiating two-way safe travel zones with our neighbours. The first of these arrangements has seen 630 workers return to the sector to service flights between Australia and New Zealand and has successfully negotiated lockdowns and other interruptions by using a state by state approach.

Domestically, Australia's aviation sector is showing strong signs of recovery. Prior to the lockdowns in Melbourne and more recently NSW, Queensland, Western Australia and Northern Territory, both Qantas and Virgin Australia were on track to return to 80-100% of their pre-COVID capacity off the back of strong leisure demand. While the lockdowns have temporarily halted that recovery, Government programs such as the Tourism Aviation Network Support program, which provided over 800,000 half-price fares to 15 tourism reliant regions across Australia were essential in getting people travelling again. They also helped build confidence in the sector making it more resilient to temporary interruptions caused by COVID 19.

However, while these restrictions are imposed the Government is also stepping in to keep planes flying and fixed cost relief through extending the successful Domestic Aviation Network Support, Regional Airline Network Support and Airservices Australia fee waiver measures. In addition, the Government is providing further assistance to the sector through subsidising training for 30 per cent of the ground handling workforce and providing grants to airports to help them meet their security costs.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Telecommunications
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 13 May 2021 regarding Petition EN2412 to expedite work to improve mobile coverage in the Clyde and Clyde North areas of Victoria.

I note the concerns raised in the petition that residents living in Clyde and Clyde North have intermittent unacceptable mobile coverage. Following receipt of the petition, I sought an update from the mobile network operators (MNOs) - Optus, Telstra and TPG Telecom (formerly Vodafone Hutchison Australia) on their mobile networks in the Clyde and Clyde North area and any plans they had for future network investment.

Telstra acknowledged the significant urban growth in Clyde, Casey and surrounds, and that to meet that demand they are progressing the construction of a new mobile tower at Clyde North, with a forecast completion date of August this year. Telstra is also progressing negotiations with TPG Telecom (TPG) to seek approval to co-locate Telstra equipment on TPG's Casey Fields tower, and are in the early stages of identifying appropriate sites to deliver additional new mobile infrastructure in Clyde East, Clyde North East and Berwick East.

TPG has advised that their new mobile site at Casey Fields has been operating since November 2020 and they are seeing a significantly improved experience for TPG customers in the immediate surrounding areas as a result. This is a commercially funded site, not a tower funded under the Mobile Black Spot Program. This site has been built to accommodate co-location and, as noted above, Telstra has expressed interest in installing their equipment at the site, which will improve coverage for Telstra customers in the surrounding area. TPG are also planning to upgrade this site to 5G, which will further increase capacity and speeds. Subject to approvals, TPG expects this upgrade to take place later in the year.

Optus advised that they are also progressing to a new base station at Casey Fields. Subject to agreeing lease terms and obtaining development application approval, Optus forecasts construction to commence before the end of 2021. Optus is also pursuing options for a number of other new sites in the Clyde area.

The Australian Government understands the importance of connectivity for all Australians and is committed to improving communications services. In major urban areas, such as in Clyde and Clyde North, mobile investment is being driven by strong competition and economic pressures rather than being subsidised through the Mobile Black Spot Program. As noted above, all three of the major MNOs are investing in new mobile infrastructure in these areas of urban growth, including through the deployment of new 5G technology.

While the mobile carriers are investing to improve mobile coverage in Clyde North, Clyde and surrounding areas, there are a number of factors, such as buildings (including their internal structure) or other physical obstacles such as trees, that can interfere with mobile reception and therefore impact a user's ability to obtain or maintain a mobile signal at any given time or place. The particular type of handset and its settings can also affect mobile reception. For example, customers will need a compatible mobile device in order to access the MNOs 4G and 5G networks.

Wi-Fi calling is also available on the mobile carriers' networks for use with a compatible device allowing some customers to call and text over a Wi-Fi broadband connection. This can be particularly helpful in areas that have poor indoor mobile reception. Residents of Clyde and Clyde North should contact their mobile service provider to identify ways to improve their mobile reception or to obtain further advice regarding Wi-Fi calling.

For residents who do not already have a broadband connection, the NBN Co Limited (NBN Co) website indicates that the National Broadband Network (NBN) is now available in the Clyde and Clyde North area. Further information about network availability in the area is available on the NBN Co website at www.nbnco.com.au.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Social Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 12 May 2021, concerning Petition EN2421, which calls on the House of Representatives to consider not giving access to the "Live List" of online misinformation to health experts as it may interfere with freedom of speech.

I am aware that an online petition is requesting the Australian Government to mandate digital platforms to provide a 'Live List' of misinformation to health experts to help counter the spread of false information in regards to COVID-19.

The Government is committed to promoting the rule of law and the rights and protections we enjoy as a democratic nation. Of these, our right to free speech and free expression is one of the most highly valued and fiercely protected. The ability of citizens to speak freely and openly is the hallmark of a robust democracy.

However, there has never been an absolute right to free speech in Australia. Free speech is balanced against other considerations, such as whether speech is harmful, threatening, offensive or defamatory. This includes disinformation and misinformation that harmfully misleads the Australian public on matters of public importance.
When it comes to issues such as health and safety, including the COVID-19 pandemic, it is critical that the Australian community seek information from legitimate and authoritative sources.

The Government supports actions by digital platforms to combat disinformation and misinformation. Following the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's Digital Platforms Inquiry in 2019, the Government tasked the Australian Communications and Media Authority to oversee the development of a voluntary industry code of conduct to address disinformation and misinformation on digital platforms.

The Digital Industry Group Inc. (DIGI) developed the Australian Code of Practice on Disinformation and Misinformation (Code) on behalf of the Australian digital industry and released the Code on 22 February 2021. The Code has been adopted by Twitter, Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Redbubble , TikTok, Adobe and Apple, with other digital platforms also encouraged to sign up. Further information on the Code is available on the DIGI website, digi.org.au/disinformation-code/.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Medicare
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition (EN2497) - Medicare levy payments to only exclude age pensioners and students. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

On 17 September 2020 I responded to petition EN1587, which I have attached. I note that petition EN2497 raises the same concerns and has the same principal petitioner as petition EN1587, and therefore I refer you to my response to petition EN1587.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1587 - Medicare Levy. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

I understand the petitioner's concerns that all Australians should pay their fair share of tax and Medicare levy. In Australia, a resident's income tax liability—for most taxes and for Medicare levy—is based on taxable income, after deductions are taken into account.

A basic principle of the Medicare levy is that it applies to an individual's taxable income from all sources. The fact that taxpayers are required to pay the Medicare levy on taxable Government assistance payments they receive—just as taxpayers are required to pay the Medicare levy on any wage and salary income—is consistent with this basic principle.

However, low-income earners are not liable for the Medicare levy. This is consistent with the progressive nature of income tax, which means those on lower taxable incomes pay less tax. The Medicare levy low­income thresholds ensure that households do not pay Medicare levy if their taxable income is below a certain level, and the amount payable is phased-in over a certain income range. These arrangements ensure that the liability of people to pay the Medicare levy reflects their financial capacity to contribute to the total cost of national health care, and is not merely a payment for service.
The Government considers the current Medicare levy settings to be appropriate.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Charitable Organisations
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 12 May 2021, concerning Petition EN2506 about unsolicited communications from charities.
I sympathise with the petitioners' frustration generated by unsolicited phone calls.
There are four elements of regulation relevant to these communications.

The Do Not Call Register (the Register) operates to help minimise the number of unsolicited telemarketing calls people receive. Organisations are not allowed to call a number (or have someone else call a number) for telemarketing if that number is on the Register. Telemarketing is any call where the caller is aiming to sell, advertise or promote goods and services. This applies to all marketers, whether in Australia or overseas calling mobile or fixed numbers.

The Spam Act 2003 (Spam Act) regulates the sending of unsolicited commercial electronic messages (spam). Commercial electronic messages include those that seek to offer or promote goods or services. They include messages sent by email, short message service (SMS), multimedia message service (MMS) or instant messaging. Messages that contain purely factual information are not considered spam under the Spam Act.

Some organisations are given exemptions from these requirements because they operate in the public interest. This includes registered political parties, registered charities, educational institutions (when contacting current and former students) or government bodies. These organisations can contact you to ask for donations or payments even if your number is on the Register.

The arrangements allow charities to call numbers listed on the Register or to send messages, to seek donations relating to goods and services they provide. Charities contribute to the broader public interest, and so the arrangements provide an exemption for these organisations so they can continue their work.

However, charities are bound by Telemarketing Standard. The standard sets out when and how people can be contacted. Further information about the standard is available from the Australian Communication and Media Authority's (ACMA's) website www.acma.gov.au or by calling 1300 792 958.

The Fundraising Institute Australia (FIA) administers a code of conduct for fundraising in Australia. The Code applies to FIA members and is a condition of membership. The Code requires FIA members to comply with a donor's request not to receive any future solicitations. The Code can be accessed at:
https://fia.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/CodeFINAL-2018.6.28-KW.pdf.

Based on the information available, it is not clear whether there has been a breach of the Telemarketing Standard. If the petitioners believe there has been a breach they may lodge a complaint with the ACMA.
Thank you for bringing the concerns raised in Petition EN2506 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Gender and Sexual Orientation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 24 May 2021 regarding House of Representatives Petition EN2533, which relates to the motion presented by Senator Malcolm Roberts opposing the use of gender-neutral language.

The Australian Government fully respects the rights of all Australians irrespective of their gender identity. The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 prohibits discrimination on the grounds of gender identity, sexual orientation and intersex status in many areas of public life, including employment, education and in the provision of goods, services and facilities.

The Government supports the rights of individuals to make use of any titles, pronouns or descriptors they prefer while also encouraging respect for the preferences of others. The Government will use language in communications that is appropriate for the purpose of those communications and is respectful of its audiences.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Telecommunications
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 24 May 2021 concerning Petition EN2604 about National Relay Service (NRS) user registration.
I understand and appreciate the petitioners have concerns about their privacy and telecommunications accessibility for people with disabilities.

The petition notes that Australians without disabilities are not required to register to use the Standard Telephone Service. Proof of identity is a standard requirement in accessing and using many other services. NRS user information is held on a strictly confidential basis, with retention and access arrangements adhering to the Australian Privacy Principles.

Registration details are held by the NRS provider on behalf of the Australian Government and are not to be provided to anyone else without the user's permission, unless required by law to do so, such as calls to emergency services.
The Australian Privacy Principles can be found at: oaic.gov.au/privacy/Australian-privacy-principles
The NRS privacy policy can be found at:
communications.gov.au/documents/national-relay-service-privacy-policy

Registration enables the NRS provider to know how many people are using the NRS and how they are using it, such as how many users use different call channel types. This helps plan how the NRS is resourced, for example, how many relay officers are needed to ensure different call channel types are appropriately staffed. This helps to effectively manage call wait times for users.

Once a user is registered, this is no impact on their day to day use of the service. I encourage all NRS users to register with the NRS so they may continue to access the NRS. Users can contact the NRS Helpdesk to register or find out more about registration.
The NRS Helpdesk can be contacted via:
Online Form - communications.gov.au/node/19659
Post - PO BOX 691, Ballarat, VIC 3353
Thank you for bringing the concerns raised in Petition EN2604 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Ethiopia: Tigrayans
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter regarding Petition Number EN2613 on Tigray, Ethiopia.

Australia remains gravely concerned by the situation in Tigray, and reports of egregious human rights atrocities, including systemic sexual and gender-based violence. We are particularly concerned by the recent escalation in violence and the end to the unilateral ceasefire. Australia has urged all parties to negotiate a permanent ceasefire to end violence and stop atrocities.

We have also joined international calls for safe, timely and unimpeded humanitarian access in the region given the urgent need for supplies to reach those in need. In addition to Australia's $3 million contribution to the World Food Programme, we are a top ten donor to the UN Central Emergency Response Fund which, on 4 June, released US$14.8 million for Ethiopia. Through the Australia Assists program we are also providing targeted personnel support to UN agencies operating in Tigray.
Australia continues to raise concerns directly with the Ethiopian Government and at the UN Human Rights Council and the UN Security Council.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 21 June 2021 enclosing Petition EN2630 concerning inclusion of parents as immediate family for an automatic exemption from the travel restrictions.

As you are aware, the former Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Peter Dutton MP, and I, as the current Minister for Home Affairs, have responded to several petitions which outlines the Australian Government's position on including parents as an automatic exemption category from the travel restrictions for travel to Australia.

As outlined in the response to previous petitions, currently, no consideration is being given to include parents as immediate family members or include parents as an additional exemption category for travel to Australia.

On 2 July 2021, the National Cabinet agreed to temporarily reduce the current international passenger arrival caps to manage the pressure on quarantine facilities managed by state and territory governments. As such, it is imperative that international travel to Australia is limited to exceptional circumstances only, as per the current exemption categories.

We acknowledge that this is a challenging and difficult time for Australians who are separated from their loved ones overseas. However, the travel restrictions regime has kept the broader Australian community safe from the health risks posed by discretionary international travel, and has also ensured that we can bring Australian's home safely.

The Government is committed to regularly review Australia's travel restrictions policy as national and global circumstances in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic evolve, and continues to take a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, informed by the latest health advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

In line with this commitment, on 2 July 2021, the National Cabinet also agreed to formulate a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response which outlines Australia's pathway out of the COVID-19 pandemic.
As outlined in this plan, easing travel restrictions and opening of international borders will be a phased approach that will be triggered by expert advice.

Whilst the travel restrictions remain in effect, individuals who are not automatically exempt from the travel restrictions, including parents of Australians, but have a compelling reason to travel, can submit a travel exemption request for an assessment against the exemption categories outlined on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2630 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 23 June 2021, concerning Petition EN2633 on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout and choice of vaccine.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the Australian Government's highest priority. For this reason, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines have been, and continue to be, based on the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

People eligible for vaccination now have been identified taking into account the current supply of vaccines and public-health, medical and epidemiological evidence on who would be most at risk of contracting COVID-19, or of serious illness if they contracted COVID-19. This is why the rollout has been focused on people who live or work in high-risk settings, people with underlying medical conditions and older people.

Australia's priority remains to vaccinate as many people as soon as possible, to protect the health and wellbeing of Australians. While Australia currently has low levels of community transmission, there remains a chance of spread from hotel quarantine, which could lead to high levels of community transmission and severe disease. Therefore, it is important that Australians are vaccinated with the Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines that have been determined safe and effective by the Therapeutic Goods Administration and are currently available as part of Australia's rollout.

It is important to note the AstraZeneca vaccine remains highly effective at preventing death and severe illness among people who have contracted COVID-19 and that the incidence of the blood-clotting syndrome is very rare.

ATAGI consider that the individual benefit-to-risk balance of vaccination with COVID-19 vaccine AstraZeneca in Australia varies with age. Older adults have an increased risk of severe outcomes from COVID-19 and a lower risk of thrombosis with thrombocytopenia (the rare clotting syndrome). The risk of ongoing health issues and death from COVID-19 is highest in older age groups, particularly rising from 60 years of age.
Pfizer is the preferred vaccine for people younger than 60 years old, since the risk of TTS—albeit very low—appears to be higher in younger adults.
Pfizer is recommended for people 16 years and older with:
a past history of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis
